Name: Lemon and Lime
Ingredients (comma separated): Black tea, lemon & lime flavoring
Description/Directions:
Cold brew ice tea. Quench your thirst with the delicious and zesty taste of our Lemon & Lime Cold Brew Iced Tea. Made from the finest black tea leaves and expertly blended with citrus flavors, this tea will keep you cool and refreshed throughout the day. Our Cold Brewed Iced Tea is a convenient and easy way to prepare fresh-brewed iced tea without the need to boil water, add tea bags, steep and wait for it to cool down. 
Simply add an English Tea Cold Brew Iced Tea tea bag to room temperature or cool water. Let stand for 5 minutes. Stir thoroughly and add ice to finish. Enjoy sweetened or unsweetened. From Sri Lanka, Kenya, Assam.

Name: Masala Chai
Ingredients (comma separated): Black Tea, Cardamom, Ginger Root, Cloves, Natural Cinnamon Flavor & Cinnamon Bark
Description/Directions:
Our Masala Chai tea blend combines premium Ceylon black tea with cinnamon, cardamom, cloves and ginger. In Indian culture, 'Masala' means 'a blend of spices', and 'chai' simply means 'tea.' So, Masala Chai is literally 'spiced tea'. Our interpretation tries to stay true to its definition thanks to a warm and inviting fragrance, zesty flavor, and invigorating, aromatic finish. We suggest two heaping teaspoons per 8 oz cup. Sugar or milk if desired. Steep at 212 for 7-10 minutes.

This tea contains a high level of caffeine | Steep at 212Â° for 7-10 minutes.

Blended to replicate delicious Thai restaurant tea at home with notes of coconut, cardamom and vanilla. To tickle your taste buds with a tantalizing authentic experience, prepare your own traditional Thai Iced Tea by pouring the freshly brewed tea over ice, topping it off with your choice of sweetened condensed milk or coconut milk. Name: Mint Chip Sundae
Ingredients (comma separated): Cocoa nibs, green tea, peppermint, white chocolate, cocoa powder, stevia extract, natural flavouring
Description/Directions: Nothing makes the world go round like an ice cream sundae. But did you know they were actually invented to evade the law? In late 1800s America, selling ice cream soda was illegal. So a bunch of sweet-toothed bootleggers swapped out soda for syrup â and the sundae was born. Our frosty green tea version tastes like mint chocolate chip freedom. With fresh peppermint, rich cocoa nibs and sweet white chocolate, itâs a divinely refreshing treat. Chip chip hooray!

Name: Strawberry Shake

Description/Directions: Do you know the milkshake man? Itâs said that Ivar âPopâ Coulson created the first milkshake in 1922, adding scoops of extra-rich ice cream to malted milk drinks. We think he would have loved our version of a good old-fashioned strawberry shake. Inspired by the malt shop classic, this sweet and creamy green tea combines the richness of yogurt with a bright burst of juicy strawberry and papaya. And since it has zero calories, itâs a guilt-free indulgence you can feel good about drinking. Two straws, please!

The result? An emerald-green tea thatâs refreshing and smooth. No wonder itâs Japanâs most popular drink.

Name: Kyoto Cha
Ingredients (comma separated): Pan fired green tea
Description/Directions:
Spring 2017 First Harvest "Kyoto Cha"
This spring-harvested green tea comes from large-leaf trees in the countryside between Kyoto and Iga. Its flavor is bold and nutty, yet avoids the sharpness of more matured greens when steeped at milder brewing temperatures. The distinctive fuzz of young tea leaves lines the back of this pleasantly multi-toned tea. Unique for a japanese green, in that it appears to have been lightly pan-roasted rather than steamed. A refreshing morning brew.

Name: Mao Kian Green
Ingredients (comma separated): green tea

Harvested late in March, just after the frosts of spring subside, this tea captures the full-bodied profile of a fine green without the bitterness of more mature plants. Subtly sweet and delicately grassy, its elegant flavor hits all the right notes. Pleasant hints of evergreen and fresh morning dew linger in the warm aftertaste.

swirled record

Whether you call it âsoft iceâ like the Scandinavians, âmerry creamâ like the Lebanese or âsoft whipâ like the Irish, we can all agree that vanilla soft serve ice cream is a timeless and delicious dessert. So it was only a matter of time before we brought the most popular ice cream flavour in the world to your teacup. This decadent infusion has all the creamy vanilla sweetness of the soft serve cone you first fell in love with as a kid. The only difference? We left out the calories and added a swirl of lemongrass. Sweet!

Description/Directions: We love a classic martini as much as the next secret agent. But every once in a while â no judgment please â we just want a really good appletini, extra sour. We made an infusion so mouthpuckeringly satisfying, even Bond would approve. Itâs packed with juicy apple, blackberry leaves and a dash of beetroot, so it steeps an eye-catching red. With its fresh and tangy green apple zip, itâs the ultimate summer cocktail.

Name: Raspberry Mojito
Ingredients (comma separated): Apple, raisins, hibiscus blossoms, carrot, beetroot, peppermint, lime, raspberries, rose petals, natural and artificial strawberry flavouring.
Description/Directions:
Fresh mint, tangy lime and a splash of rum. Is there any way to improve on a classic mojito? Sureâ¦Just add raspberry! A touch of fruity sweetness makes this classic cocktail sing, and colours it a beautiful, smile-inducing bright pink. So of course our mojito tea needed to include everyoneâs favourite berry. The result? A rose-tinted tisane thatâs fruity, minty and utterly refreshing. Served over ice with a splash of rum, it tastes like a summer afternoon on a sunny Havana patio. In short, pure heaven.

Best served: Hot Tea / Iced Tea / Tea Pop

Name: Samurai Mate

After drinking a cup of this extraordinary mate blend, you'll feel ready to do battle with your day! Traditional yerba mate elegantly balances the spirit of chai spices with the essence of tropical fruit undertones culminating in a graceful mosaic of flavors. Not for the faint of heart, this is one herbal blend that will give you the warrior's energy you need to get through even the toughest of days.

This tea contains a moderate level of caffeine | Steep at 212Â° for 5-10 minutes.

Description/Directions: Immerse yourself in peace and tranquility with our Peach Serenity herbal tisane. The slight dryness of the Florida orange flavor balances with the naturally sweet, mellow and mineral rooibos. Our Rooibos blended with fresh orange flavor makes the perfect partner for your morning meal. Because it's completely caffeine free, you can enjoy another cup in the evening, too.

Pour your freshly steeped tea over some ice for a cool treat and you may as well have captured summertime in a cup! All you need is tiny pink umbrella as the finishing touch.

Name: Iron Goddess King
Description/Directions:
180-190 F, 1 to 2 teaspoon and rinse. Brew for 40 seconds, reuse up to 8 times. 
Tie Guan Yin or Iron Goddess of Mercy is a premium Chinese oolong tea originated from Anxi county in Fujian province. With slight oxidation, the result is a smooth flavor with hints of refreshing orchids. Iron goddess king is the next step up from our thousand miles and is great for everyday drinking.

Ginger Lily blossoms from Taiwan are blended with high mountain oolong tea (Alishan Jin Xuan) to yield a tea that has an earthy oolong taste with a light, sweet ginger finish with pleasing honey notes. A lovely, approachable, refreshing tea. Call it summer in a cup.

Name: Black tea, peppermint, chocolate, pink peppercorns, sprinkles
Ingredients (comma separated): Huang Jin Gui Oolong from Anxi in Fujian Province, natural vanilla flavouring
Description/Directions:
a sweet romance

Weâre still searching for the secret to eternal bliss, but weâre pretty sure one cup of this blend will get you at least five minutesâ worth. It all starts with the very best leaves: a premium oolong from Chinaâs Fujian Province called Huang Jin Gui. A popular wedding gift in China, Huang Jin Gui is prized for its pretty yellow colour and romantic floral scent. Here we bring out this special leafâs orchid aroma with a touch of vanilla. The result? A perfectly balanced, subtle cup thatâs equal parts rich, creamy and floral. Feeling blissful yet? (MK Kosher).

Best served: Hot Tea / Tea Latte /
KOSHER

Combining savory almond with the bright, fruity-floral taste of Taiwanese oolong tea, our Almond Oolong is great on its own, as well as the perfect dessert complement. Smooth, clean and unroasted almond nutty aroma. Full, rounded body and sweet marzipan flavor. The only question now is, is it ok to have two desserts in one evening?

The rich complexity of oolong tea lays a smooth foundation for a majestic cup, packed with savory spice notes and hypnotic aroma. Elements of cinnamon, ginger, cardamom, chicory and cocoa nibs harmoniously blend together creating an exciting, yet truly satisfying chai that is sure to tickle your taste buds.

Our tempting puâerh adds an extra dash of cinnamon to the campfire classic, so itâs rich, warming and packed with fudgy goodness. Want to live dangerously? Break out your biggest mug and brew it as a latte. Then top with extra fluffy marshmallows for the ultimate cold-weather indulgence. Donât worry â thereâs sâmore where that came from.

But with all the benefits of puâerh â and next to no calories â this is one little indulgence you can feel great about drinking. Try it with hot frothed milk and a shot of coffee liqueur. It just doesnât get sweeter than that.

If you liked Mocha Latte, youâll love English Toffee

Some people call it fairy floss. Others go for spun sugar. We like the classic âcotton candy.â But whatever you want to call it, we can all agree on one thing: itâs seriously delicious and ridiculously fun. And this tea was developed with our favourite carnival treat in mind. It combines nut brittle, candied mango and cotton candy sprinkles with a smooth, sweet base of green rooibos. The result? All the fun and flavour of the real thing, at next to no calories. Itâs a carnival in a cup.

Name: Le Marche Spice Rooibos
Ingredients (comma separated): Rooibos, rosehip shells, almond pieces, dried apple, hibiscus,  cinnamon spice
Description/Directions:
The Le Marche Spice Rooibos is a top grade herbal tea from South Africa. This delicious tea includes Rooibos, rosehip shells, almond pieces, dried apple, hibiscus, and cinnamon spice.

Rooibos, meaning Red Bush in Afrikaans, is grown at the altitude of 2000 feet above sea level in the Cedarberg region. Fermentation of the Rooibos turns the leaves from green to deep red and gives a slight sweet note. When brewed this tea produces a reddish orange liquid with a sweet, fruity, and spicy taste.

Research has shown Rooibos tea to be a rich natural source of antioxidants with a high level of flavonoids. The absence of caffeine makes it an ideal drink, even at night.

Name: Persian Marzipan

Name: Mudslide
Ingredients (comma separated): Rooibos, carob, coffee beans, chocolate chips, natural flavouring
Description/Directions: What happens when you mix chocolate, coffee beans, carob and cream? You get the richest, darkest, most satisfying drink around. Thatâs right â the Mudslide. You know it as a frozen cocktail made with vodka, coffee liqueur and Irish cream â maybe even a scoop of ice cream if youâre feeling wild. Our rooibos version tastes just as decadent, but wonât give you a sugar rush or a hangover. Itâs rich, creamy and dangerously addictive. Just try to resistâ¦

Name: Cinnamon Apple

Description/Directions: Like freshly baked apple pie, this blend of cinnamon, apples and Rooibos tea will send your tastebuds into overdrive. If you want to satisfy your sweet tooth without a guilty conscience, indulge in a cup for an after-dinner treat. Naturally caffeine-free

Traditionally used as a detox herbal ingredient in its native South Africa, it has a smooth, black currant-like taste that keeps us coming back for more. Here, we paired it with fruity goji berries â the tasty, much-loved super berry from traditional Chinese medicine. This is one detox ritual we could definitely get used to.

Brew at least twice to get the most out of your blend.

When brewed as directed, the large tin yields approximately 80+ servings and a small tin yields approximately 16+ servings.

Ingredients (comma separated): White tea, apple, mango, pineapple, green tea, sugar, sweet blackberry leaves, raspberries, chamomile, natural raspberry, vanilla and caramel flavouring
Description/Directions: From rich pavlovas to French macarons, nothing spells elegant quite like a beautiful fluffy meringue. And this delicately sweet tea is the perfect way to chic up your teacup. Itâs got vibrant notes of ripe raspberries, plus a heady dose of vanilla creaminess. Add in a base of white tea and youâve got a blend thatâs deliciously fresh and fruity, like a melt-in-your-mouth raspberry meringue. Perfect for those afternoon tea dates with the bestie.

Name: Jasmine Silver Needle
Ingredients (comma separated): silver needle
Description/Directions:
Fall 2016 Jasmine Silver Needle White Tea
While Jasmine-scented teas have become a staple of any well-stocked pantry, the wide variety of methods used in their production can have varying results. This Silver Needle white tea, blended with just the right touch of jasmine blossoms, strikes the perfect balance between the heady perfume of the flowers and the delicate tea's own subtle character. Simultaneously relaxing and invigorating, this gently fragrant delight succeeds in distinguishing itself from its common kin.

Name: Snow Flower
Description/Directions:
Spring 2017 Yuki Hana "Snow Flower" Shizuoka White Tea
A delicate Japanese white tea, made entirely from newly-sprouted buds picked once yearly each spring during a three-day period in which the emerging leaves are consistent in length and appearance. They reveal a beautiful bright-green hue when brewed. The taste is malty and fresh, with hints of aromatic sweetness accentuating its light, grassy notes.

Name: Sweet Lime
Ingredients (comma separated): Apple, mango cubes, mango, sugar, mango flakes, apple pomace, citric acid, sweet blackberry leaves, white tea, green tea, lime, natural lime flavoring, mango flavouring
Description/Directions:
lime of your life

Looking for a new way to cool down? Try this sweet, citrusy blend of white tea, green tea, lime and mango. Fresh, fruity and tangy, it tastes just like a cool glass of fresh-squeezed limeade â with a rich, exotic hint of mango. Try it on ice with rum and fresh mint for the ultimate mojito, or sweeten it with agave and freeze it into the most refreshing ice pops ever. The possibilities are endless.

Best served: Hot Tea / Iced Tea / Tea Pop

Description/Directions:
For those days when you're feeling a bit adventurous, steep a cup of this exotic, yet subtle twist on classic chai. We've taken the delicate flavor of white tea and blended it with familiar chai flavors and the added zesty notes of lemongrass, coconut and pineapple. Steep this aromatic beauty for a complex cup of fruit and spice that leaves the alluring essence of cinnamon dancing in its wake.

This tea contains a low level of caffeine | Steep at 212Â° for 5 minutes.

Name: Long Life Oolong

Description/Directions: Chinese oolong has some serious history. Literally called âBlack Dragon,â this ancient tea has been in everyoneâs cup â from Song Dynasty emperors to Englandâs Queen Victoria. Though we love a classic, we thought it was time to bring this primordial dragon up to the 21st Century. How did we do it? First, we added some sweet peach and apricot pieces. Then, we sprinkled some almond slices and topped it off with orange peel and safflower petals. Thereâs a little taste of history in every sipâ¦ (MK Kosher).
